setting: Dartmouth College’s library. Harvard College. Massachusetts. Washington. The narrator's home (including a bathroom, basement, and kitchen), a cabin office (a considerable distance from the house), a tiny village in northern New England, Connecticut, the Roman Forum (historical context), a boarding school (where George attends), a law school (where Dorothy works), P. T. Barnum’s grave, Figarospeech.com (a website created by the narrator). The University of Washington's "love lab." London. South Beach. Roman schools. Senate floor. Oaxaca. A living room. Greensboro, North Carolina (where the narrator worked). Washington D.C. (where the narrator lived when single). Georgetown (a part of D.C. nightlife). Detroit (a dance club setting). Afghanistan (remote parts where basketball is played). Capitol Hill. An Ivy League campus. A fundamentalist church. A conference table. A boardroom. M Street (in Georgetown). A football game. Cooper Union (New York). A bank lobby in Hanover, New Hampshire. Vermont. The New Hampshire legislature. Mount Saint Helens (volcano, in Washington, not Oregon). Indian province of Sind (captured by Charles Napier). White House (where John Roberts worked for Ronald Reagan). White House Correspondents Dinner (2005, where Laura Bush told a joke). characters: Dorothy: The narrator's wife. Returned to full-time work a year and a half ago. Works a fund-raising job at a law school. Likes to see her husband as an "inspired author" and herself as an "able enabler." Says the narrator's cashmere sweater makes his eyes look "bedroomy." Launched an argument about George wearing shorts. Is naturally sympathetic and good at conceding moods, capable of making the narrator feel sheepish by oversympathizing. Resumed her career and was promoted to vice president within eighteen months after following her husband's advice on dressing one step above her rank. Puts herself on Dorothy Junior’s side during hikes but hikes because she likes it. Made a pact with the narrator not to treat their children equally but to love them equally and deal with each situation separately. Told George not to speak to his father in a disrespectful way. Uses the backfire technique constantly, loving to oversympathize with the narrator's mood.

George: The narrator's seventeen-year-old son. Attends a boarding school as a day student. Hates the food at school and his father's stew. Used all the toothpaste. As a two-year-old, he used "argument by the stick" (fists) when words failed him. He switched the rhetoric from past to future in an argument about toothpaste. At age seven, insisted on wearing shorts to school in the middle of winter. Made a deal with his father to wear shorts to school if he wore snow pants outside. His birthday was declared "Shorts Day" by the principal. Instinctively used Aristotle's three tools of persuasion. Stuck out his lower lip when trying not to cry. Now expresses individuality by wearing ties and pants to school. Believes that meeting a pointless challenge outweighs comfort and sense. Was denied permission to sit with his friends at a football game by the narrator, who cited his age and gender. Tried the *dubitatio* technique the narrator told him about, using it on "her" while talking politics. Tried to make the narrator mad by announcing an emotion, which backfired. Got stronger than the narrator in arm-wrestling and learned his grip technique.

Narrator: An unnamed individual who discovered rhetoric through John Quincy Adams's lectures. Is the father of George and husband of Dorothy. A writer who dropped out of journalism and publishing to work by himself in a cabin office in a tiny village in northern New England. Considers himself a "confirmed hermit," "persuasion-resistant," and "advertising-immune." Owns a cat. Created the website Figarospeech.com. Was an editorial director at Rodale publishing company a few years ago. Considers himself a "lousy prognosticator of best sellers." Used the extreme choice technique to persuade his wife to name their son George. Tried to persuade George to wear pants using argument by character, logic, and emotion. Conceded to George to let him wear shorts to school. Was humiliated by losing an argument to a seven-year-old. His personal goal is to raise persuasive children. Had a former boss who used concession effectively. Returned home angry that his employer had not recognized an award his magazine won. Lived in D.C. when single. Carried a coffee mug that said "Piss Off" in New York and Greensboro. Hired an entry-level editor with a controversial bumper sticker. Has a younger brother, John. Tried to imitate John's "doll" approach with a rose and failed, sensing his own embarrassment. Considers himself not an "irony-free, straight-ahead guy." Worked in a job speaking to business execs and editors. Considered corduroy the height of male fashion. Had a fashion consultant named Joe in New Hampshire. Felt five years old when talking to Captain Kangaroo. Took over a college alumni magazine, increased advertising revenue, but did not receive a raise beyond cost-of-living increases. Clashed with a faculty dean over publishing an article in German, valuing profit and service to readers over scholarship. Apologized to Dorothy Junior to get into the car. Admired Dorothy Junior's use of the Eddie Haskell Ploy. Made a pact with Dorothy not to treat their children equally but to love them equally and deal with each situation separately. Believes girls mature more quickly than boys. His children saw him as practically wise in anything that didn't involve moving parts. Researched Quintilian. Described *dubitatio* to George. Used the "gradually speak louder" technique himself due to stage fright. Explained classical rhetoric to a lady after his daughter's temper tantrum. Is scheduled to testify before the New Hampshire legislature on broadband Internet access in rural areas. Has a dial-up connection so slow a stamped envelope gets delivered faster than e-mail. His anger is perceived by Dorothy Junior as "Yosemite Sam" funny, but his quiet, scary eyes are frightening. Can make "scary eyes." Worked for a small magazine early in his publishing career that had no fact checkers. Cluelessly placed Mount Saint Helens in Oregon in a news piece. Used the backfire technique on his editor, Bill, after making a mistake. Tries to entertain his family with puns, but they are unappreciative. Is "hit-or-miss" with rapid-response humor. His family values an occasional obscenity, skillfully uttered, as a commonplace. Stopped arm-wrestling his son. Was better at arm-wrestling due to knowing the right kind of grip. Is currently consulting with a publishing company that is bidding for a major airline’s in-flight magazine. His client has only one editor dedicated to the project, besides him, and he will help hire staff if the client wins the bid. Plans to pitch the magazine around the word "fun," including "in-flight cinema" (flip-book images) and "competitive doodling." Returned a rental car with big scrapes in Nice, France, but the worker in the return lot gave a Gallic shrug and sent him on his way without punishment. Exaggerates for effect when discussing commonplace words.

John Quincy Adams: Taught rhetoric at Harvard College from 1805 to 1809 while a United States senator. He was a "paunchy, balding thirty-eight-year-old" during his teaching years and authored a volume on rhetorical lectures.
Cat: The narrator's pet, described as "ten dumb pounds of fur," who persuades with gesture and tone of voice.

Daniel Webster: Studied rhetoric at Dartmouth College by joining the debating society, the United Fraternity (later Alpha Delta). Mentioned as a skilled lawyer, implying he couldn't get a cop to apologize. Prosecuted a murder case in Massachusetts involving Captain White. Argued a case before the Supreme Court on behalf of Dartmouth College against New Hampshire's attempt to take it over, moving Chief Justice John Marshall to tears.

Aristotle: A philosopher who understood the power of emotion as a motivator, believed emotion trumps logic, and believed in the curative powers of seduction. Identified three traits of credible leadership: virtue, disinterest, and practical wisdom. Devised a form of rhetoric for each of the tenses and liked the future best. Identified three most powerful tools of persuasion: logos, ethos, and pathos. Invented logic. Believed every point has its flip side. Quoted as saying, "He who is unable to live in society, or who has no need because he is sufficient for himself, must be either a beast or a god." Believed people must trust a persuader's judgment and essential goodness. Identified three essential qualities of a persuasive ethos: virtue, practical wisdom (street smarts), and selflessness (disinterest). His "disinterested goodwill" combines selflessness and likability. Believed emotions come from belief (what we value, know, expect) and that reality looks different under different emotions. Preferred to modify people's emotions through their beliefs. Said some emotions (sorrow, shame, humility) prevent action, while others (joy, love, esteem, compassion) work better. Identified anger, patriotism, and emulation as emotions that can get an audience to act. Called the use of fear a fallacy ("argument by the stick"). Said the easiest way to stimulate anger is to belittle a desire. Noted that young, poor, and sick people rouse to anger more easily. Said anger gets the fastest action but is not the best for deliberative argument, reserving it for courtroom rhetoric. Noted that a big crowd expects big drama in a speech. Believed the person most affected by a decision makes the best judge of it. Maintained that a slave’s testimony was invalid except under torture, and would have caned a kid.
David Hume: A philosopher quoted as saying, "Truth springs from argument among friends."

Saint Augustine: Knew that faith requires emotion. A onetime rhetoric professor and one of the fathers of the Christian Church, known for "boffo sermons" that made audiences cry. Quoted as saying, "Audi partem alteram. Hear the other side."
Frederick Kaufman: A writer who showed how the Food Network uses techniques similar to the porn industry.
Rachael Ray: A Food Network personality, used as an example of "seduction" in cooking shows.
Emeril Lagasse: A Food Network personality, used as an example of "seduction" in cooking shows.
Used car salesman: Seduced the narrator into buying a "lemon" car in Connecticut.
P. T. Barnum: A historical figure whose grave the narrator visited during a test drive.
Tom Thumb: A historical figure whose marker the narrator saw near P. T. Barnum's grave.
John F. Kennedy: A former U.S. President who deployed a chiasmus in a televised address, inspiring the Peace Corps.
Britney Spears: A pop artist quoted by the narrator.

Dorothy Junior: The narrator's daughter. Enjoys argument much less than her brother. Can be equally persuasive. Uses guilt as an emotional goal in arguments. Is spending a term as a college student in London. Has a biting tongue but knows how to restrain it to win an argument. Values comfort and sense above all else. Has the best sense of direction in the family. Ran ahead on a family hike and locked herself in the car. Demanded an apology from the narrator. Used the Eddie Haskell Ploy to bolster her standing with her parents by making an inevitable decision (not going to an unsupervised party) look like a willing sacrifice. Was allowed by Dorothy Sr. to sit with her friends at a football game. As a three-year-old, she threw a temper tantrum in a bank lobby. Is now a self-directed college junior who aspires to med school. Knew from birth that a good persuader manipulates the audience's feelings. Knew Cicero's dictum that good pathetic argument is understated. Used "Bambi eyes" to persuade the narrator. Found the narrator's anger "funny" like Yosemite Sam, but his quiet, scary eyes frightening. Practices bantering concession with the television. Used a Heinrichs commonplace ("You do whatever the hell you want, sweetheart") at nursery school, which was not shared by the school.

Cicero (Marcus Tullius Cicero): History's greatest orator. Came up with three goals for persuading people: stimulate audience's emotions, change its opinion, get it to act. Believed the most effective rhetoric disguises itself. Divorced his wife of thirty years and married a teenager at sixty. Used digressions to change the tone and rhythm of an argument. Claimed humor was one of the most persuasive rhetorical passions. Believed the appearance of struggling for self-control amplifies the mood. Said a genuine emotion persuades more than a faked one. Believed decorum that works for one persuader may not work for another, even in front of the same people. Taught that one cannot assume a character that strays too far from one's own, stating, "Indeed, such diversity of character carries with it so great significance that suicide may be for one man a duty, for another (under the same circumstances) a crime." Listed decorum first among ethical tactics. Said an audience should be receptive, attentive, and like/trust the speaker. Said you want an audience to be attentive, trusting, and willing to be persuaded. Mentioned a tactic to hype objectivity: seem to deal reluctantly with something you are eager to prove. Believed the appearance of struggling for self-control amplifies the mood. His dictum states that good pathetic argument is understated. His speeches were known for making people say, "What a great speech," leading to agreement rather than commitment. Noted that the Greeks put out several manuals on humor, all unintentionally funny. Banter was his favorite kind of humor, which led to his death. Cited an example of bantering concession during a trial in the Forum. Advised Romans not to make jokes about a shocking crime or a pitiful victim.
Homer: Quoted regarding Aphrodite's girdle and blandishing persuasion.
Socrates: Character in a *National Lampoon* parody of Plato's *Republic*, depicted as winning arguments by knockout.

John Gottman: Research psychologist who proved that successful couples argue differently than doomed ones. Conducted research in the eighties and nineties at the University of Washington's "love lab," videotaping hundreds of married couples. Announced findings in 1994.

Vice President Dick Cheney: Fought (not argued) when he urged U.S. senator Pat Leahy to commit an autoerotic act on the Senate floor. His aggressive stance on cruel and inhumane treatment of suspected terrorists gave President Bush breathing room on the Iraq war.
U.S. senator Pat Leahy: Was urged by Dick Cheney to commit an autoerotic act.
George Foreman: Makes an argument when he tries to sell a grill.

Homer Simpson: Offers a legitimate argument when demonstrating intellectual superiority to dolphins. Argues with Marge in the future tense. Quoted on drugs. A character whose conservative talk show host, B. T. Barlow, commits a rhetorical error.
Mariah Carey: Pitches an argument when she sings "We belong together."
Howard Dean: Fought (not argued) when saying Republicans "have never made an honest living."
Yogi Berra: Made an argument when saying, "It's not the heat, it's the humility."

John Kerry: Won presidential debates against President Bush on points, but Bush won the election because the audience preferred the man, not the words. Annie, the narrator's friend, tried to sway votes for him in 2004. Kathy believes he would raise taxes.

President Bush: His popularity improved after presidential debates with John Kerry, despite Kerry winning on points. Won the election. Chose Cheney as a running mate to appear moderate. A "master of *dubitatio*." His "Bushisms" make red-staters love him. Kathy plans to vote for him in 2004 because she believes he will keep taxes down. His White House used commonplaces in policy labels (No Child Left Behind, Operation Iraqi Freedom, Clear Skies, Healthy Forests Initiative, Culture of Life, Marriage Protection). Promoted tort reform by referring over and over to "frivolous lawsuits."
F. Lee Bailey: Mentioned as a skilled lawyer, implying he couldn't get a cop to apologize.
Aristophanes: Playwright who said persuasion can make "the lesser side appear the greater." Quoted as saying, "Even if you persuade me, you won’t persuade me."
Plato: Thought persuasion making "the lesser side appear the greater" was a bad thing. Thought attaching values to audiences sounded like relativism.
Lord Nelson: Quoted as saying, "never mind maneuvers, go straight at ’em."
Barry White: Musician whose music is suggested for setting a mood.
Jimmy Stewart: Shy actor who needed "surrogate seduction" from director Frank Capra to kiss Donna Reed in *It's a Wonderful Life*.
Donna Reed: Actress who kissed Jimmy Stewart in *It's a Wonderful Life*.
Frank Capra: Director of *It's a Wonderful Life*, used "surrogate seduction" to get Jimmy Stewart to kiss Donna Reed.
Henry Kissinger: Nixon’s national security adviser. Used a classic persuasive method of laying out five alternatives, with his preferred one in the middle, for Nixon to choose.

Nixon: President who inevitably chose Henry Kissinger's preferred option from a list of five alternatives. Chose Agnew as a running mate to appear moderate. Failed in rhetorical virtue; Watergate violated the American notion of fair play.
Cardiologist: Author of *The South Beach Diet*.
Marge: Homer Simpson's wife.
Brad: A celebrity, formerly coupled with Jen.
Jen: A celebrity, formerly coupled with Brad.
O.J.: A historical figure whose guilt can be a blame issue. His case was compared to the Captain White murder case.
Little Orphan Annie: A character who sings about the future, demonstrating that it deals with bets, not facts.
Ned Flanders: A born-again Christian from *The Simpsons* who uses demonstrative rhetoric.
Moe the bartender: A character from *The Simpsons* who makes a weak attempt at deliberative rhetoric.
Uncle Randy: A man who decides to divorce his wife of thirty years to marry a surfing instructor.
Aunt: Uncle Randy's wife of thirty years.
Surfing instructor: The younger woman Uncle Randy plans to marry.
Caller: A person on a radio show who criticizes George Bush.
Next Caller: A person on a radio show who expresses anger at the previous caller.
Host: The host of a radio show who engages in tribal talk.
Bono: Mentioned as a cosmic authority.
Mother: A generic character in an example argument about monkey bars.
Father: A generic character in an example argument about monkey bars.
A husband: A generic character in examples of couple arguments.
A wife: A generic character in examples of couple arguments.
Principal: The principal of George's school who declared George's birthday "Shorts Day" and wore culottes.
Calvin: A character from the comic strip *Calvin and Hobbes* who uses concession effectively.
Dad: Calvin's father in *Calvin and Hobbes*, who tries to teach Calvin to ride a bike.
Boss: The narrator's former boss, who came from a sales background, never overtly disagreed with the narrator, but used concession to get him to do the opposite of his proposals.
Izaak Walton: Author of *The Compleat Angler*.
George H. W. Bush: Quoted as saying, "I care."
Arlo Guthrie: Yelled, "I wanna kill! Kill!" when registering for the draft.
Kenneth Burke: A modern rhetorician who declared decorum "perhaps the simplest case of persuasion" and offered an inventory of decorous skills in 1950.
Narrator's mother: Was fourteen when *Gone with the Wind* came to the local theater in Wayne, Pennsylvania, in 1939, and had to sit in the balcony with the family's black cook due to segregation.
Rhett Butler: A character from *Gone with the Wind* whose line "Frankly, my dear, I don't give a damn" was considered profanity.

Eminem: A hip-hop artist and subject of the movie *8 Mile*, described as a "foulmouthed master of decorum" who won a rap battle by revealing his opponent attended prep school, demonstrating superior decorum.
John: The narrator's younger brother, who successfully used the term "doll" when giving a rose to a woman in Georgetown. Described as an "irony-free, straight-ahead guy."
Hare Krishna: A person selling roses in Georgetown.
Dean Martin: Mentioned by the narrator as someone who might say "Here you go, doll."
Cary Grant: Mentioned as an example of someone who would look "terrific" but indecorous in a hip-hop club.

Joe: A salesman at a men's store in New Hampshire who became the narrator's fashion consultant. Advised the narrator to mimic colors and patterns of expensive shirts and ties. Counted Captain Kangaroo among his clients.
Captain Kangaroo (Bob Keeshan): A client of Joe, the salesman, who gave the narrator advice on buying a suit. Had a "bad haircut."
Comte de Buffon: The man who first said, "Style makes the man."

Senator Bob Packwood: An Oregon Republican senator who was an effective feminist on Capitol Hill but whose career was wrecked by a "decorum disaster" involving chasing female staff, leading to his resignation.

Jimmy Carter: A former U.S. President described as a "great campaigner" who used decorum by wearing conservative suits and smiling broadly. Also described as intellectually endowed but less effective due to more IQ than street smarts. Failed in rhetorical virtue by speaking of a "national malaise," going against American values.
Emily Post and Miss Manners: Authors associated with mandatory politesse, contrasted with rhetorical decorum.
Martha Stewart: Mentioned in comparison to ancient decorum manuals.
The One-Minute Manager: Mentioned in comparison to ancient decorum manuals.
COO (Chief Operating Officer): An example of a business executive whose behavior might be indecorous for a subordinate to imitate.
Pentagon: The U.S. Department of Defense, which failed to train officers in Iraqi decorum until three years after the Iraq invasion.

Isocrates: Quoted as saying, "The argument which is made by a man’s life is of more weight than that which is furnished by words." Also quoted as saying, "Speech is the leader of all thoughts and actions."
Janet Jackson: Used as an example of rhetorical virtue to her fans, who lost virtue when her audience expanded to include those who didn't appreciate exposed nipples on network television.
Jesus Christ: Used as an example of pure virtue. Evangelical Protestants might find a persuader trustworthy if they think the persuader wants to do what Jesus would do.
Julius Caesar: Used as an example of rhetorical virtue. His ethos was so great that Shakespeare said he could change offensive rhetoric "to virtue and to worthiness." Assassinated.
Moses: Mentioned in contrast to persuasive virtue.
Abraham: Mentioned in contrast to persuasive virtue.

Bill Clinton: His impeachment by the House of Representatives for dalliance and lying mystified Europeans due to differing cultural values regarding leaders' sexual loyalty. Chose Gore as a running mate to appear moderate. Told the special prosecutor, "That depends on what your definition of 'is' is," redefining a term. Fond of the slogan "Make Abortions Safe and Rare" and "Abortions Should Be Safe, Legal, and Rare."
François Mitterrand: Former French president whose wife and mistress both attended his funeral, illustrating French cultural differences regarding leaders' affairs.

Atticus Finch: A character from *To Kill a Mockingbird* who, despite being seen as virtuous by viewers, loses rhetorical virtue and persuasive power among the townsfolk by defending a black man charged with raping a white woman, due to straying from 1930s white Southern cultural values.
Gregory Peck: The actor who played Atticus Finch, whose portrayal makes the narrator's wife "almost swoon."

Lincoln (Abraham Lincoln): Used informal language, including "darkie jokes" and the N-word, before his presidency to win over racists with rhetorical virtue, talking the audience's talk. His outward attitude was an effective ethos gambit to stop slavery's expansion. A "wizard" at *dubitatio*. Used it to get elected president. Was a political nobody in 1860. Had freakishly big hands, aerodynamic cheeks, a Western rube's accent. Addressed New York's elite at Cooper Union. Spoke in a harsh whine, warned the crowd they wouldn't hear anything new. His dubious opening conveyed sincerity. His country-bumpkin image disguised a brilliant political analyst.
John McCain: Rarely talks about his heroism as a prisoner in Vietnam, but others do, illustrating the character reference technique.
George Washington: Master of the "tactical flaw" device, using his dimming eyesight to win the fealty of his officers during the Revolutionary War.
George W. Bush: Made a smooth "opinion switch" by first opposing and then fighting for the Department of Homeland Security, without apology or being called a waffler.
Eddie Haskell: A character from *Leave It to Beaver* whose manipulative politeness is the basis for the "Eddie Haskell Ploy."

Job: A character from the Bible who is subjected to suffering by God at Satan's bet, and who eventually challenges God, illustrating God's powerful ethos. God bragged about his feats, like inventing the whale, to Job.
Satan: A character from the Bible who bets Jehovah that Job would curse God.
Jehovah: The name for God in the Bible, who demonstrates immense ethos by challenging Job's right to argue. Mentioned as unlikely to use the passive voice.
Muhammad Ali: Mentioned as someone whose audience appreciates boastful hyperbole, making bragging effective for him.
Shakespeare: Quoted regarding Julius Caesar's ethos.
Aunt Sally: The narrator's sister, a ballroom dance instructor.
Bluto (John Belushi's character from Animal House): Lacks practical wisdom but has selfless goodwill and virtue (anarchy/revenge). Becomes a U.S. senator.
Otter: A wiser character in *Animal House* who proposes a plan after Bluto's speech.
Dean Wormer: Expels the fraternity in *Animal House*.
Marmalard: Mentioned by Bluto as "dead."
John Adams: Former U.S. President, intellectually endowed but less effective due to more IQ than street smarts.

Herbert Hoover: Former U.S. President, intellectually endowed but less effective due to more IQ than street smarts. Failed in practical wisdom by following traditional economics and trying to balance the budget during a depression.
Edison: An example of practical wisdom.
Einstein: Lacks practical wisdom compared to Edison.
Han Solo: An example of practical wisdom.
Yoda: Lacks practical wisdom compared to Han Solo.
Captain William Bligh: Commander of the *Bounty*, mediocre when following rules, but showed practical wisdom by navigating a small boat 3600 miles 3600 miles after mutiny.
Indiana Jones: Showed practical wisdom by shooting a master swordsman instead of fencing.
Agnew: Nixon's running mate, chosen to make Nixon appear moderate.
Gore: Clinton's running mate, chosen to make Clinton appear moderate.
Machiavelli: Said inconsistency is a useful leadership tool.
Quintilian: A chief rhetorician of the early Roman Empire, a Spaniard, who explained that a speaker might feign helplessness to appear honest.
Christoph Martin Wieland: Quoted as saying, "To be not as eloquent would be more eloquent."
Alexander Hamilton: Wrote anonymous letters in *The Federalist* to disguise his "interest" and pretended he never attended the Convention.
James Madison: Wrote anonymous letters in *The Federalist* to disguise his "interest" and pretended he never attended the Convention.
John Jay: Wrote anonymous letters in *The Federalist* to disguise his "interest" and pretended he never attended the Convention.
Kid (example): A teenager in an example argument who wants to borrow his father's car.
Father (example): The father in the example argument about borrowing a car.
Roosevelt: Showed practical wisdom when he broke old rules, promoted deficit spending, and became a hero during a depression.
Marie Antoinette: Her lousy ethos made the "Let them eat cake" quote believable, even if her enemies planted it.
Hamlet: Lacked practical wisdom, followed a ghost's directions.
Harold Holzer: A Lincoln scholar.
Dartmouth president: A legendary figure known for thoughtful silences who died during a speech at MIT.
Her: The person George was talking politics with, on whom he used the *dubitatio* technique.
Henry Peacham: A new character, quoted on the orator's ability to lead hearers to any affection.
Matrons: A couple of ladies who observed Dorothy Junior's temper tantrum.
Protagoras: A famous Sophist who said food tastes bitter to an invalid and the opposite to a healthy person.
Stoics: A group of Greeks who believed pain was the secret to all emotions, and good passions were the absence of pain.
Matt Damon: Actor who played a character in *Good Will Hunting* who used first-person storytelling for a joke.
Robin Williams: Actor who played the therapist in *Good Will Hunting*.
Sam: The "spandex miniskirt king" from the movie *Ruthless People*, who tried to change his mistress's mood with a sex tape.
Mistress: Sam's mistress in *Ruthless People*, who misunderstood his intentions regarding a sex tape, thinking it showed a murder.
B. T. Barlow: A conservative talk show host character in *The Simpsons* who commits a rhetorical error by forgetting pathetic volume control.
Mayor Quimby: A character from *The Simpsons* who is questioned by B. T. Barlow.
Captain White: A well-known ship captain murdered in Massachusetts, whose case was prosecuted by Daniel Webster.
Chief Justice John Marshall: The Chief Justice of the Supreme Court who was moved to tears by Daniel Webster's peroration in the Dartmouth College case.
Yosemite Sam: A cartoon character whose angry demeanor Dorothy Junior compared to her father's.
Hitler: A demagogue mentioned as invariably starting speeches quietly before turning up the volume.
Billie Holiday: A musician whose music is associated with introspective emotions like sorrow.
Demosthenes: A fiery Athenian orator whose speeches made people say, "Let's march!" due to his pathetic appeal.
Mary: A girl who got into Harvard early decision, mentioned by the narrator's parent to their kid.
Three Stooges: Characters whose actions a kid might emulate.
Older cousin: A role model for a daughter, riding a Suzuki motorcycle.
High school quarterback: A role model for a nineteen-year-old, who enlisted in the army.
Joneses: A generic family used in the phrase "keeping up with the Joneses," illustrating competitive jealousy.
Bill: The narrator's editor at a small magazine.
Artie Fufkin: The publicist in *This Is Spinal Tap*, who uses a backfire defense.
Michael Behe: A Lehigh University biologist and leading proponent of intelligent design, who argues some biological phenomena are too complex for Darwinism.
Charles Napier: A British general who captured the Indian province of Sind in 1843 and sent a one-word telegram: PECCAVI.
John Roberts: Chief Justice, who worked for Ronald Reagan and advised the White House on a Saint Patrick's Day greeting.
Ronald Reagan: President, for whom John Roberts worked.
Laura Bush: Former First Lady, who told a public joke about her husband at the White House Correspondents Dinner in 2005.
Calvin Coolidge: His ethos is mentioned in relation to joke-telling.
Lady Astor: Bantered with Winston Churchill.
Winston Churchill: Bantered with Lady Astor.
Dixy Lee Ray: Governor of Washington, who pointed out the narrator's mistake about Mount Saint Helens.
Steve Jobs: Mentioned hypothetically as a designer.
Pablo: A hypothetical person in an example of the passive voice.
Marcia: A hypothetical person in an example of the passive voice.
Elder (in Cicero's example): Called a young man a "pup" in a bantering exchange.
Young Man (in Cicero's example): Used bantering concession against an elder in the Forum.
Talking Head (on TV): A character on television with whom Dorothy Jr. banters.
President (Laura Bush's husband): His ratings got a boost from Laura Bush's joke.
I.R.A.: Mentioned in John Roberts's witty comment.
Soviet Union: Mentioned in a Cold War joke about condoms.
Americans: Mentioned in a Cold War joke about condoms.
Doc (in anecdote): A doctor who gives bad news and then good news about an affair.
Man (in anecdote): The patient with a rare illness.
Annie: The narrator's friend, a passionate Democrat from Ohio living on the East Coast. She called Ohioans to try and sway votes for Kerry in 2004.
Kathy: Annie's former college roommate, lives in Ohio, plans to vote for Bush in 2004 because she doesn't want her taxes to go up.
Professor Harold Hill: Character from *The Music Man*, who used commonplaces to sell band instruments.
Ben Franklin: Used anadiplosis.
Thomas Jefferson: Kept commonplace books.
Mark Twain: Quoted on public opinion.
New Boss (example): A hypothetical new boss whose commonplaces can be researched.
Mary (example): A hypothetical person to be hired for "Value-Driven Management."
Mr. Burns: A character from *The Simpsons*, owner of a nuclear power plant, who prefers to call a "meltdown" an "unrequested fission surplus."

world_state: Rhetoric is described as a "three-thousand-year-old art of persuasion." John Quincy Adams taught that rhetoric could "mould the mind of man to the will of the speaker, and yield the guidance of the nation to the dominion of the voice." The narrator believes rhetoric teaches how "to argue without anger" and offers "a source of social power." Rhetoric is also described as "the art of influence, friendship, and eloquence, of ready wit and irrefutable logic," harnessing "the most powerful of social forces, argument." Argument is pervasive, playing with emotions, changing attitudes, leading to decisions, and encouraging purchases, forming "a real-life Matrix, the supreme software that drives our social lives." Rhetoric serves as argument's decoder. The ancients considered rhetoric the essential skill of leadership, central to higher education, and it helped create the world's first democracies. Rhetoric faded in academia during the 1800s but is now gaining popularity among undergraduates. "Seduction" is a form of argument that can lead to "consensus," which is an audience's commonsense thinking or a shared faith in a choice. Faith requires emotion, and logic alone rarely gets people to act; they must desire the act. Argument is inherent in nature, as seen in territorial marking. Figures of speech can yield surprising power. The distinction between fighting and arguing: In a fight, each disputant tries to win; in an argument, they try to win over an audience. Argument aims for agreement, fighting aims for domination. Seduction is a form of argument, the rhetorical opposite of fighting, and a "good thing" that manipulates, leading to long-term commitment. Argument by the stick (using fists) never persuades, only inspires revenge or retreat. Cicero's three goals for persuasion are to change the audience’s mood, mind, or willingness to act. These are ordered by increasing difficulty: stimulating emotions (easiest), changing opinion, and getting the audience to act (most difficult). The "commitment ratio" is a method to measure if people actually do what you ask them to (divide "Okays" by follow-throughs). The "Goldilocks technique" is used by retailers, offering lower-priced junk and high-end goods to make mid-priced items seem "just right." Leadership branding coaches teach CEO wannabes to embody their company, emphasizing compelling life stories and desirability over aggression or brains. Corporate recruiters and headhunters look for persuaders and team builders, not aggressors, in executive material. A demagogue is a power-mad dictator who uses rhetorical skills for evil, dreaded by ancient rhetoricians. The South Beach Diet is an example of a successful persuasion campaign using emotional appeal (image of bathing attire/vacation) and "no-big-deal" tactics (delicious, doctor-designed, foolproof, fast, healthy weight loss). Rhetorical devices include: - Concession: Rhetorical jujitsu that uses an opponent's moves to one's advantage. (Also called Concessio). - Syncrisis: Reframes an argument by redefining it. - Commonplace: A shared attitude or belief, a building block of persuasion. - Antithesis: An opposing idea, a "shotgun marriage of contrasting thoughts." - Dirimens copulatio: "A joining that interrupts," a form of amplification. - Amplification: A rhetorical tactic that turns up the volume by layering points. - Argumentum a fortiori: "Argument from strength," where if something works the hard way, it's more likely to work the easy way. - Chiasmus: A crisscross figure that repeats a phrase with its mirror image. - Chanticleer fallacy: The logical cheat of assuming A caused B because B followed A. - Enthymeme: Aristotle's "neat bundle of logic." - Prolepsis: Anticipatory concession, agreeing in advance to what the other person is likely to say. - Eristic: The name for debating that seeks to win points. Aristotle's three traits of credible leadership are virtue, disinterest, and practical wisdom. Cicero's five-step method for constructing a speech includes invention, arrangement, style, memory, and delivery. Emotion trumps logic. The three basic issues of rhetoric, according to Aristotle, are Blame (dealing with the past), Values (dealing with the present), and Choice (dealing with the future). Any issue involving persuasion can be categorized into one of these. "Dialectic" is a type of argument that seeks to discover absolute truth, rather than persuade people. "Forensic rhetoric" (judicial argument) deals with the past tense, issues of justice, blame, guilt, and punishment, often used in courtrooms. "Demonstrative rhetoric" (epideictic) deals with the present tense, praise and condemnation, values, separating good from bad, distinguishing groups or individuals, and describing those who meet or fail community ideals; it is the communal language of commencement addresses, funeral orations, and sermons, giving a tribal identity. "Deliberative rhetoric" deals with the future tense, choices, mutual goals, and "the advantageous" (expedience); it is the most pragmatic kind of rhetoric, skipping right/wrong and good/bad in favor of expedience, promising a payoff, and relying on public opinion rather than a higher power. "Orphan Annie’s Law" states that a successful argument about the future cannot stick to facts because facts do not exist in the future; it deals with conjecture and choices. "Argument's Rule Number One" is to never debate the undebatable (what is permanent, necessary, or undeniably true), but instead to focus on goals. Using the "conditional mood" (e.g., "would" instead of "will") can leave an opening in an argument. The "extreme choice technique" involves proposing an extreme choice first to make the desired choice sound more reasonable. "Digressions" can be used to change the tone and rhythm of an argument. Phrases like "What should we do about it?" and "How can we keep it from happening again?" act as "rhetorical WD-40 lubricant" to switch arguments to the future tense. "Anticipatory concession" (a persuasion alert) involves producing audience objections before they think of them to make listeners more malleable. "Inarguable" refers to what is permanent, necessary, or undeniably true; morals are considered inarguable in deliberative rhetoric. "Control the issue" is a rhetorical tool to focus an argument on blame, values, or choice, with productive arguments centering on choice. "Control the clock" is a rhetorical tool to keep an argument in the right tense, especially the future for debates over choices. Democrats and Republicans are noted for often using the present tense, which is effective for stirring up their base but less so for conducting democracy. Aristotle's three most powerful tools of persuasion are: Argument by character (ethos), Argument by logic (logos), and Argument by emotion (pathos). Rhetoric teaches techniques like the persuasive use of decorum, argument jujitsu, and tactical sympathy. - **Logos**: Argument by logic. Its techniques use what the audience itself is thinking. - **Ethos**: Argument by character. Employs the persuader’s personality, reputation, and ability to look trustworthy. A sterling reputation is persuasive. "A person’s life persuades better than his word." Lying is unpersuasive. In Greek, ethos originally meant "habitat," and it has to do with a person's ability to fit in with a group's expectations. - **Pathos**: Argument by emotion. Appeals to the heart. Forms the root of the word "sympathy." A successful persuader must learn how to read the audience’s emotions. - Logos, ethos, and pathos appeal to the brain, gut, and heart of the audience, respectively, and form the essence of effective persuasion. They usually work together to win an argument. - **Hypophora**: A figure of speech that asks a rhetorical question and then immediately answers it, allowing one to anticipate audience skepticism. - **Concession**: A logical tactic, using the opponent’s argument to one's own advantage. The trick to concession is to find the flip side of every point. - **Sympathy**: A pathetic tactic, registering concern for the audience’s emotions and then changing the mood to suit the argument. It means aligning oneself with the listener’s mood and showing concern. The great orator transforms himself into an emotional role model, showing the audience how it should feel. - **Oversympathizing**: A technique that makes someone’s mood seem ridiculous without actually ridiculing it. - **Backfire**: A technique where an attempt to provoke a negative reaction results in a positive one. - **Decorum**: The concession side of ethos. Defined as the art of fitting in, matching the audience’s expectations for a leader’s tone, appearance, and manners. The Latin word *decorum* meant "fit" or "suitable." It is the art of fitting in everywhere, not just polite company. Survival belongs to the decorous. It tells the audience, "Do as I say *and* as I do." The speaker should sound like the collective voice of his audience, a walking, talking consensus. To show proper decorum, one should act the way the audience *expects* one to act, not necessarily like the audience itself. Kenneth Burke declared decorum "perhaps the simplest case of persuasion." Decorum follows the audience’s rules; one cannot be indecorous and persuasive at the same time. It can make the difference between persuading an audience and getting thrown out. Decorum that works for one persuader may not work for another. An ethos that fails to fit one's actual personality is usually indecorous. Decorum is the art of the appropriate. It is a source of rhetorical strength, giving people a sense of group identity. It counts even more in places where the consequences of indecorous behavior are the most dire. It is the better part of valor. Cicero listed decorum first among ethical tactics. - **Argument Tool: DECORUM**: Your audiences find you agreeable if you meet their expectations. - **Persuasion Alert: Aporia**: A rhetorical device where one wonders openly or admits inability to fathom a reason, causing the audience to unconsciously start reasoning for you. Romans saw doubt as a rhetorical device. - **Useful Figure: Dialysis**: A "this-not-that" figure of speech, which makes wisdom seem more serious if put cryptically. - **"Style makes the man"**: A saying attributed to comte de Buffon, which the narrator refutes, stating, "Style makes the occasion." - **"Always dress one step above your rank"**: A piece of advice for career advancement. - **"The personal is political"**: A concept particularly relevant for politicians, meaning their private life affects their public perception and persuasiveness. Persuasion does not depend on being true to yourself, but on being true to your audience. - **Deliberative argument**: Is not about the truth, but about choices, and persuasive decorum changes to match the audience. - **The Lincoln Gambit**: A strategy for converting character into a tool of persuasion. - **The Perfect Audience**: An audience that is receptive (sitting still), attentive (willing to listen closely), and well disposed toward you (liking and trusting you). - **Ethos (deeper dive)**: Requires the audience to trust your judgment and essential goodness. Likable knuckleheads make bad leaders. The audience must consider you a good person who wants to do the right thing and will not use them for nefarious purposes. - **Three Traits of Persuasive Leadership (Aristotle's ethos)**: 1.  **Virtue**: The audience believes you share their values. 2.  **Practical wisdom (or street smarts)**: You appear to know the right thing to do on every occasion. 3.  **Selflessness (or disinterest)**: The audience’s interest seems to be your sole concern. - **Virtue (rhetorical)**: Means upholding the values of a group. It does not require purity of soul or universal goodness; one simply must *be seen* to have the audience's values. It changes from audience to audience. Roman *virtus* meant "manliness"—good sportsmanship, respect for values, and all-around nobility. - **Persuasion Alert (Interrupting yourself)**: Addressing a different audience (even a virtual one) keeps the original audience on its toes. - **Litotes**: Understates a point ironically. - **Values in deliberative argument**: Used as a tool of ethos, not as a subject of debate. - **Persuasion Alert (Relativism)**: The point of rhetoric is to make one argue more effectively, not to transform one's character. - **Decorum (special kind)**: The ability to match the audience’s beliefs, distinct from clothing or table manners. - **Bragging**: An argument tool to be used only if the audience appreciates boastful hyperbole. - **Character Reference**: An argument tool where others do your bragging for you. - **Tactical Flaw**: An argument tool to reveal a weakness that wins sympathy or shows the sacrifice made for the audience. - **Opinion Switch**: An argument tool where, when an argument is doomed to go against you, you heartily support the other side. A persuader can also pretend they were for the new stand all along. - **The Eddie Haskell Ploy**: An argument tool to make an inevitable decision against you look like a willing sacrifice on your part. - **Rhetorical values**: Do not necessarily represent "rightness" or "truth"; they merely constitute what people value (honor, faith, steadfastness, money, toys). - **Rhetoric as an agnostic art**: It requires more adaptation than righteousness, adapting to the values of the audience. - **Candidus**: Latin for "white," the root of "candidates" and "candy." "Candid" used to mean "openminded." - **Ethos enhancer (overwhelming with erudition)**: A common, if ham-handed, method to make an audience take your word for it. - **Rhetoric as awareness and attitude**: More than just technique. - **Practical wisdom (phronesis)**: The second major element of ethos. The audience thinks you know how to solve the problem at hand. It is common sense that can get things done, an instinct for making the right decision on every occasion, and flexibly wise leadership. It is more Edison than Einstein, more Han Solo than Yoda. It does not entail looking up decisions in books or sticking to universal truths. - **Argument Tool: PRACTICAL WISDOM**: The audience thinks you know how to solve the problem at hand. Aristotle’s word for this kind of wisdom is *phronesis*. - **Three tools to get an audience to trust your decision (related to practical wisdom)**: 1.  **Show off your experience**: Experience usually trumps book learning. It is fine to brag about experiences, rather than yourself. 2.  **Bend the rules**: If the rules don't apply, don't apply them, unless ignoring them violates the audience’s values. 3.  **Seem to take the middle course**: Humans instinctively prefer a decision that lies midway between extremes. In an argument, it helps to make the audience think your adversary’s position is an extreme one. - **Proposal structure**: Every proposal should have three parts (not necessarily in this order): payoffs, doability, superiority. - **Inconsistency as a leadership tool**: Keeps the ruler’s subjects off guard (Machiavelli). - **"Consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds"**: A quote used by the narrator. - **Disinterested goodwill**: Aristotle's third ethos asset, combining selflessness and likability. The benevolent persuader shares everything with his audience and makes them believe he has nothing personal at stake, appearing "free of any special interest." - **Disinterest (historical context)**: In earlier times, a reputation for selflessness determined whether a politician got elected. The founders considered rich people the most "interested." Eighteenth-century leaders were anxious to show disinterest, some even gave away their fortunes. This continued into the early nineteenth century with "log cabin" stories, showing a man's ability to be beholden to no one. - **Libertas**: Originally meant both freedom and frankness. Free people (those not beholden to a source of income) could speak freely because they were "disinterested." - **Disinterest (modern application)**: Make your audience believe in your selflessness by seeming either wholly objective or nobly self-sacrificing. - **Argument Tool: THE RELUCTANT CONCLUSION**: Act as though you felt compelled to reach your conclusion, despite your own desires. Make it sound as if you reached your opinion only after confronting overwhelming evidence. - **Disinterest technique**: Act as if the choice you advocate hurts you personally. - **Rhetorical virtue**: Can be lost if a leader goes against their nation's values (e.g., Carter's "national malaise" speech) or violates notions of fair play (e.g., Nixon's Watergate). - **Practical wisdom**: Demonstrated by breaking old rules when necessary (e.g., Roosevelt's deficit spending during a depression) rather than strictly following traditional rules (e.g., Hoover's budget balancing). Lacking it can lead to poor decisions (e.g., Hamlet following a ghost's directions). - **Goodwill breakdown**: A persuader's poor ethos can make negative, even false, statements about them believable (e.g., Marie Antoinette's "Let them eat cake" quote). - **Ethos (deeper dive)**: Counts more than any other aspect of rhetoric because it puts your audience in the ideal state of persuadability (attentive, trusting, and willing to be persuaded). You want them to consider you a role model. - **Rhetorical trickery**: The best trick is to make it seem you have no tricks. - **Quintilian's advice**: A speaker might choose to feign helplessness by pretending to be uncertain how to begin or proceed with his speech, making him appear as an honest man rather than a skilled rhetorician. - **Argument Tool: DUBITATIO**: Don’t look tricky. Seem to be in doubt about what to say. The Romans called this technique *dubitatio*, as in "dubious." It lowers expectations and causes opponents to "misunderestimate" you. - **Nervous Speaker Tip**: Use butterflies. An audience will sympathize with a clumsy speaker (a tactical flaw). Gradually speak louder to sound as if you're gaining confidence from the speech's contents. - **Speech openings**: A slow beginning works better than the classic opening joke. Most people start with an attention span of at least five minutes. - **Dubitatio (one-on-one)**: When your partner finishes talking, look down, speak softly and slowly until you're ready to make your main point, then stare intensely into their eyes to convey passionate sincerity. - **Ethos and trickery**: Works best when it disguises its own trickery, even to the point of deliberate ineptness. It requires *performing* personality and reputation, not just "being yourself." Ethos is not karma; it can be started afresh in every argument. - **Ancient Greek preference for plain speech**: Audiences trusted plain-spoken leaders more than skilled ones, preferring "pure" Greek over "fancy" talk, which they called "Asian." - **Manipulation vs. Sharing in rhetoric**: Rhetoric involves manipulation, but also sharing. - **The Tools (summary of chapter's main points)**: - **Disinterest**: The appearance of having only the best interest of your audience at heart, even to the point of sacrificing for the good of others. - **The reluctant conclusion**: Act as if you reached your conclusion only because of its overwhelming rightness. - **The personal sacrifice**: Claim that the choice will help your audience more than it will help you; even better, maintain that you’ll actually suffer from the decision. - **Dubitatio**: Show doubt in your own rhetorical skill. The plain-spoken, seemingly ingenuous speaker is the trickiest of them all, being the most believable. - **Pathos**: Means more than just "feelings," also refers to physical sensations or suffering. The medical term "pathology" comes from it. Affects an audience's judgment, as confirmed by neurological research showing the limbic system (emotions) tends to overpower rational brain parts. Comes from belief, experience, and expectation. Works best at the end of an argument and poorly at the beginning. Should build gradually. Can work subtly in small groups. Is most effective when underplayed, with the persuader appearing to struggle to contain emotions. Requires simple speech, as ornate language belongs to ethos and logos. Less evokes more in pathetic terms. Makes the difference between agreement and commitment. - **"Pathetic"**: In classical rhetoric, it was a compliment, meaning the persuader bore the burden of emotion. An argument cannot be rhetorically pathetic unless it is sympathetic. - **Sophists**: Believed pathos affects an audience's judgment. - **Neurological research**: Confirmed the Sophists' theory that the limbic system (seat of emotions) tends to overpower the more rational parts of the brain. - **Emotions**: Come from belief (about what we value, know, and expect). Reality looks different under different emotions. Some emotions (sorrow, shame, humility) prevent action, making people introspective. Other emotions (joy, love, esteem, compassion) work better. Emotions that get an audience to act (anger, patriotism, emulation) arouse people's tribal instincts and require identification. - **Stoics**: Believed pain was the secret to all emotions, with good passions being the absence of pain. - **Storytelling**: The best way to change an audience's mood. It should be vivid, directly involve the speaker or audience, and create a vicarious experience and expectation. Works for every kind of emotion, including humor, and is more effective than name-calling. - **Emotional Volume Control**: A rhetorical tool that advises against visibly exaggerating emotions, instead letting the audience do that for you. Underplaying emotions, in an apparent struggle to contain oneself, gets better results. - **Simple speech**: A pathetic tactic; don't use fancy language when emotional. Ornate speech belongs to ethos and logos; plain speaking is more pathetic. - **Peroration**: The apt time for pathos in a speech. - **Humor**: Ranks high in persuasiveness and improves ethos, calming people and making the speaker appear above petty squabbles. However, it is awful at motivating action, as people rarely want to do anything else when they laugh. - **Fear**: Aristotle called its use a fallacy ("argument by the stick") because it compels people to act, and compulsion precludes choice, leaving only naked instinct. - **Identification**: Action requires identification with the speaker and the action promoted. - **Anger**: A person who desires something is especially susceptible to anger if their ability to assuage that desire is frustrated. Young people, the poor, and the sick rouse to anger more easily. The easiest way to stimulate anger is to belittle that desire. It is useful for personal lawsuits, arising from a sense of belittlement. Anger gets the fastest action but is not the best emotion for deliberative argument (decisions about the future) because angry people tend not to think far ahead; it was reserved for courtroom rhetoric. - **The Belittlement Charge**: An argument tool to show your opponent dissing your audience's desires. - **Patriotism**: A rhetorical group loyalty that looks into the future. It is not idealism, but burns for a country (e.g., stars and bars) rather than an idea (e.g., the Constitution). It can be for any group (high school, team, company). It is stirred by comparing the audience with a successful rival group. It is often triggered by something negative, such as when a group is under threat. It has a personal side as a form of competitive jealousy. - **Emulation**: An emotional response to a role model. For it to work, one needs to start with a model the audience already looks up to. It also comes out of an atavistic need to belong. - **The Unannounced Emotion**: An argument tool that advises against advertising a mood in advance, as audiences will resist the emotion if prepared for it. Instead, invoke it, allowing emotions to sneak up on people. - **Group setting**: Most persuasive emotions (humor, anger, patriotism, and emulation) work best in a group setting. Ornate speech belongs to ethos and logos; plain speaking is more pathetic. - **Anger**: Often arises from a sense of belittlement. You can direct an audience’s fury at someone by portraying his lack of concern over their problems. - **Patriotism**: Attaches a choice or action to the audience’s sense of group identity. You can stir it by comparing the audience with a successful rival. - **Emulation**: Responds emotionally to a role model. The greater your ethos, the more the audience will imitate you. - **Unannounced emotion**: Lets you sneak up on your audience’s mood. Don’t tip them off in advance. They’ll resist the emotion. - **Passive voice**: A thousands-year-old rhetorical device used by scientists to calm passions. It encourages passivity and calms the audience, making it a pathos trick. It can be used to describe wrongdoing by a friend or coworker while calming the audience, but should not be used when the speaker is the culprit, as audiences may perceive it as "weaseling out." - **Argument Tool: THE PASSIVE VOICE**: Pretend that things happened on their own. - **Backfire**: A technique that inspires sympathy through a *mea culpa* routine that exaggerates the emotions the audience feels. It is generally ineffective in politics unless the persuader is the widow of a popular, recently deceased incumbent. It is a risky technique because the audience might comply with an exaggerated request. - **Humor**: The best calming device for most emotions, except anger. It relieves anxiety by releasing impulses. One way to inject it is to invent a neologism that only the audience would understand. -   **Wit**: Drier than urbanity, mildly amusing, and plays off the situation rather than wordplay. -   **Facetious humor**: Covers most jokes, its sole purpose is to make people laugh. Different groups identify through their commonplaces, which also determine self-identity. **Metastasis**: A manipulative rhetorical figure that involves skipping over an awkward subject. - **Issue**: What an argument is about, which always has two-sided descriptions. - **Framing**: The process of defining an issue by finding the persuadable audience’s commonplaces, defining the issue in the broadest context, and then dealing with the specific problem in the future tense. -
